elements.content: A series of bis(arylthio)ethers, trans-1,4-bis(phenylthio)-2-butene (L ), trans-1,4-bis(2-pyridylthio)-2-butene (L ), trans-1,4-bis(2-pyrimidinylthio)-2-butene (L ), trans-1,4-bis(4-methyl-2-pyrimidinylthio)-2-butene (L ), and trans-1,4-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazolylthio)-2-butene (L ), have been designed and synthesized, and the reactions of these ligands with AgX salts (X = NO3 -, ClO4 -, or BF4 -) lead to the formation of eight new metal−organic coordination polymers exhibiting from 1D to 3D frameworks. Single-crystal X-ray analysis showed that complexes 1, 2, and 4 exhibit 2D layer frameworks, and 3, 5, 6, and 8 have 1D chain structures, while 7 is a 3D coordination network. In these polymers, a variety of geometries of AgI and coordination modes of the organic ligands were observed due to the different numbers and relative orientation of N donors in the terminal groups of these ligands. In addition, the influences of counteranions and solvent coordination on the framework formations have been discussed. These results indicate that both steric and electronic effects of the ligands play important roles in affecting the structural topologies of such metal−organic coordination architectures.

These results indicate that both steric and electronic effects of the ligands play important roles in affecting the structural topologies of such metal-organic coordination architectures.

elements.content: Eight novel metal−organic coordination polymers exhibiting from 1D to 3D frameworks are synthesized by the reactions of AgX salts (X = NO3 -, ClO4 -, or BF4 -) and a series of bis(arylthio)ethers ligands, which have the same backbones, and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. The results reveal that the nature of ligands is a determining factor in controlling the structural topologies of the metal−organic supramolecular architectures, which are also dependent on the counteranions and solvent used.
elements.clean_text: Eight novel metal-organic coordination polymers exhibiting from 1D to 3D frameworks are synthesized by the reactions of AgX salts (X = NO3 -, ClO4 -, or BF4 -) and a series of bis(arylthio)ethers ligands, which have the same backbones, and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. The results reveal that the nature of ligands is a determining factor in controlling the structural topologies of the metal-organic supramolecular architectures, which are also dependent on the counteranions and solvent used.

elements.content: Nowadays, the rapid development in the active area of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) continues to produce various supramolecular structures with fascinating compositions and topologies, along with potential applications as functional solid materials. It is well-known that the overall topology of coordination polymers mainly depends on the coordination preferences of metal centers and the backbone of the bridging ligands. In particular, the rational design of organic building blocks plays the key role in adjusting the coordination frameworks, and the nature of the coordinating donors may lead to the formation of unique networks with desired properties and functions. On the other hand, AgI is a favorable and fashionable connecting node for the construction of coordination polymers due to its coordination diversity and flexibility, and it shows positive coordination tendency with sulfur or nitrogen donors. Recently, some subtle factors such as the configurations of ligands, the spacers linking the terminal groups, counteranions, metal/ligand ratio and solvents in modifying the networks of AgI coordination polymers with bis(phenylthio)alkane ligands have been investigated by our group and others; however, similar studies on bis(heteroarylthio)alkane ligands are still limited. Nitrogen and sulfur atoms in such ligands may have different abilities when coordinating to the AgI center due to the differences of their donor properties and relative numbers/orientation; thus, it may give rise to interesting results in tuning the coordination architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, the rapid development in the active area of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) continues to produce various supramolecular structures with fascinating compositions and topologies, along with potential applications as functional solid materials. It is well-known that the overall topology of coordination polymers mainly depends on the coordination preferences of metal centers and the backbone of the bridging ligands. In particular, the rational design of organic building blocks plays the key role in adjusting the coordination frameworks, and the nature of the coordinating donors may lead to the formation of unique networks with desired properties and functions. On the other hand, AgI is a favorable and fashionable connecting node for the construction of coordination polymers due to its coordination diversity and flexibility, and it shows positive coordination tendency with sulfur or nitrogen donors. Recently, some subtle factors such as the configurations of ligands, the spacers linking the terminal groups, counteranions, metal/ligand ratio and solvents in modifying the networks of AgI coordination polymers with bis(phenylthio)alkane ligands have been investigated by our group and others; however, similar studies on bis(heteroarylthio)alkane ligands are still limited. Nitrogen and sulfur atoms in such ligands may have different abilities when coordinating to the AgI center due to the differences of their donor properties and relative numbers/orientation; thus, it may give rise to interesting results in tuning the coordination architectures.

elements.content: We report herein eight new AgI coordination polymers exhibiting from 1D to 3D patterns, with a series of bis(arylthio)ethers ligands bearing a trans-2-butene backbone (see Chart ). With this report, we attempt to explore the influences of the different numbers and relative orientations of nitrogen atoms in terminal groups, as well as counteranions on the coordination tendency of the donor atoms to AgI and the resulting structures of the complexes with such ligands.

elements.content: Synthesis of Ligands. Ligands L 1 and L 4 were prepared according to the reported procedures, and the others were synthesized similarly as briefly described bellow:  the reaction of aromatic thiol (1 mmol) with trans-1,4-dibromo-2-butene (0.5 mmol) in EtOH at 70−80 °C gave rise to the required ligand as a white powder.

Caution! Although we have met no problems in handling AgI perchlorate during this work, it should be treated with great caution owing to their potential explosive nature.

X-ray Crystallography. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements for complexes 1−8 were carried out on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) K. The determinations of unit cell parameters and data collections were performed with Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-squares refinements. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL. All non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were added theoretically, riding on the concerned atoms and refined with fixed thermal factors. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table .

[Ag L 1 NO 3 ] ∝ 1. In the structure of 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center is a distorted tetrahedron comprised of a pair of S atoms from two distinct L 1 and a pair of O atoms from two NO3 -. All four Ag−donor distances (see Table ) are within the normal range for such coordination bonds. Each L 1 links two adjacent AgI centers to form a 1D zigzag chain. Further, each NO3 - is in a bidentate fashion and bridges two AgI ions from two neighboring chains, forming a 2D layer parallel to the ab plane. In another description, the AgI ions are bridged by NO3 - groups alternately to form [AgONO] n 1D chains, which are further cross-linked by L 1 to form a 2D pattern. This 2D network contains two types of 22-membered ring units:  rhombic (Type A) and rectangular (Type B) (Figure a). In each type of the repeating unit (A or B), four AgI ions are coplanar, and the dihedral angle between the two Ag4 planes is 35.3(3)°. Both A and B units arrange alternately along the b axis and expand along the a axis (Figure b). It should be noted that all ligands adopt a trans configuration and two terminal phenyl groups within each ligand are parallel to each other, lying on the two sides of the repeating unit alternatively. In addition, such 2D layers stack along c axis with offset and left no channels.

Results and Discussion

 [Ag L  1   NO  3  ]  ∝   1. In the structure of 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center is a distorted tetrahedron comprised of a pair of S atoms from two distinct L  1   and a pair of O atoms from two NO3 -. All four Ag-donor distances (see Table ) are within the normal range for such coordination bonds. Each L  1   links two adjacent AgI centers to form a 1D zigzag chain. Further, each NO3 - is in a bidentate fashion and bridges two AgI ions from two neighboring chains, forming a 2D layer parallel to the ab plane. In another description, the AgI ions are bridged by NO3 - groups alternately to form [AgONO] n  1D chains, which are further cross-linked by L  1   to form a 2D pattern. This 2D network contains two types of 22-membered ring units: rhombic (Type A) and rectangular (Type B) (Figure a). In each type of the repeating unit (A or B), four AgI ions are coplanar, and the dihedral angle between the two Ag4 planes is 35.3(3)°. Both A and B units arrange alternately along the b axis and expand along the a axis (Figure b). It should be noted that all ligands adopt a trans configuration and two terminal phenyl groups within each ligand are parallel to each other, lying on the two sides of the repeating unit alternatively. In addition, such 2D layers stack along c axis with offset and left no channels.

{[Ag L 2 ](NO 3 )} ∝ 2. Different from L 1 , the terminal group of L 2 is a pyridine ring. In 2, the geometry of AgI is a slightly distorted trigonal plane comprised of two pyridine N donors and one S atom from three distinct L 2 ligands, with all Ag−donor bond distances within the range expected for such species (see Table ). The AgI ion is almost at the coordination plane (deviated by only 0.02(3) Å), and the sum of the three N−Ag−N bond angles is close to 360°. Two such AgI centers [Ag(1) and Ag(1A)] are linked by S−C−N bridges of the terminal groups of two distinct L 2 ligands to form an eight-membered centrosymmetric metallacycle with a chair configuration. In each eight-membered ring, the Ag··· Ag distance of 3.29(2) Å is within the summed van der Waals radii of two free AgI ions (3.44 Å), indicating the presence of ligand-supported Ag−Ag interactions. These similar cases were also observed in the AgI complexes of other nitrogen-containing heterocyclic thioethers.

One L 2 links two eight-membered metallacycles stated above through its terminal (2-thiopyridyl) groups to form a distorted rectangle [Ag2 L 2 ]4 unit, in which eight AgI ions lie on two parallel planes [Ag(1)−Ag(1C)−Ag(1E)−Ag(1F) and Ag(1A)−Ag(1B)−Ag(1D)−Ag(1G)] (Figure a). In this repeating unit, the L 2 ligand adopts two kinds of configurations and coordination modes. In type A, the ligand adopts a trans configuration and coordinates to AgI with its pyridine N donors with the bridged Ag(1A)···Ag(1B) distance of 8.27(2) Å. Two pyridine groups stretch to the opposite directions with respect to the central CC bond and almost parallel to each other (with the dihedral angle of only 1.7°), and the pseudo-torsion angle of C(12A)−S(1A)···S(1B)−C(12B) is −67.0°. The distance of two S atoms is 5.78(3) Å and that of the two coordinated N atoms is 4.82(3) Å. In type B, the ligand adopts a cis configuration and links four AgI ions with both N and S donors. Two pyridine groups are almost parallel to each other, inclined to the central double bond to form a dihedral angle of only 0.7°, and the pseudo-torsion angle of C(5A)−S(2A)···S(2G)−C(5G) is 22.4°. The two coordinated S atoms have a distance of 6.42(3) Å, and that of the two coordinated N atoms is 6.74(3) Å. The eight-membered ring units are linked by the alkyl spacers of L 2 and extend along the a- and c-directions to form a 2D network (Figure b).

elements.content: It is clear to see that the introduction of the N donor into the terminal group of L 2 results in different coordination modes of AgI and network structures. In 1, only the S atoms of L 1 coordinate to AgI and nitrate anions are in a bidentate fashion. While in 2, both N and S donors bound to AgI with nitrate uncoordinated, which may be attributed to the introduction of the N donors that complete the coordination sphere of AgI in such a steric environment.

elements.content: {[Ag L 2 (CH 3 CN)](ClO 4 )} ∝ 3. The 1D polymeric complex 3 is obtained by the reaction of L 2 with AgClO4 instead of AgNO3 for 2, and the coordination geometry of AgI is slightly distorted trigonal planar as that in 2, but comprised of two pyridine N donors from adjacent ligands and one N donor from CH3CN. All Ag−N bond distances fall in the range of 2.27(2)−2.36(1) Å (Table ), which are within the normal range for such coordination. The AgI center is almost at the AgN3 coordination plane with a deviation of 0.022 Å, and the sum of three N−Ag−N bond angles is close to 360°.

elements.content: In 3, L 2 ligands bridge the adjacent AgI centers using two terminal pyridine N donors to form a linear chain along the a direction (Figure a) and two ligands around each AgI center adopt different configurations (Types A and B). Type A ligand adopts a trans configuration with the bridged Ag···Ag distance of 11.75(2) Å. Two terminal pyridine groups are parallel and stretch to the opposite directions with respect to the central CC bond. Within this ligand, the S···S and the coordinated N···N distances are 6.43 and 9.33 Å, respectively. Type B ligand adopts a cis configuration with a bridged Ag···Ag distance of 10.83 Å. The two terminal pyridine groups are inclined to the central double bond with a dihedral angle of 11.2°, and the pseudo-torsion angle of C(10)−S(2)···S(2B)−C(10B) is 16.4°. The S···S distance within such ligand is 6.43 Å, which is almost equal to that in type A, but the distance of the two coordinated N atoms is 6.69 Å, being significantly shorter than that in type A.

elements.content: Each AgI center in the chain shows weak interactions with one S atom and one AgI from an adjacent chain (Ag···S and Ag···Ag distances:  3.18 and 4.47 Å) and an S atom of another adjacent chain with a Ag···S distance of 3.01 Å. Considering these weak interactions, such 1D chains arrange to form a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure b). In addition, the interplanar distance between two neighboring parallel aromatic rings of the adjacent chains is ca. 3.4 Å, and the corresponding centroid-to-centroid distance is ca. 3.7 Å, indicating the presence of face-to-face π−π stacking interactions that further stabilize the crystal structure.

elements.content: [Ag L 3 NO 3 ] ∝ 4. The geometry of AgI is a slightly distorted tetrahedron comprised of two N donors and one S donor from three distinct L 3 ligands, and one O donor from NO3 -, with all four Ag−donor bond distances within the range expected for such coordination (see Table ), except the Ag−S bond (2.769(1) Å), which is longer than those in other complexes discussed in this paper. Two AgI centers [Ag(1) and Ag(1A)] are linked by two N−C−S bridges of distinct 2-thiopyrimidine groups from two L 3 ligands to form an eight-membered centrosymmetric metallacyclic unit, which adopts a chair conformation (similar to 2). In each eight-membered ring, the Ag···Ag distance is 4.37(2) Å and the pyrimidine rings located at the symmetric site are parallel, while the adjacent pyrimidine rings are inclined to each other with the dihedral angle of 5.8(1)°. Two NO3 - are stretched to the opposite directions.

One L 3 ligand bridges two AgI centers with two distinct N donors and links two other AgI centers with its S donors, forming a [Ag2 L 3 ]4 unit in which eight AgI ions lie on two parallel planes [Ag(1)−Ag(1B)−Ag(1D)−Ag(1F) and Ag(1A)−Ag(1C)−Ag(1E)−Ag(1G)] (Figure a). In this repeating unit, all ligands adopt a trans configuration and two terminal pyrimidine groups are parallel to each other, lying on two sides of the repeating unit alternatively, being different from that in 2. These [Ag2 L 3 ]4 macrocycles are connected by the alkyl linkers of the ligands, extending along the [0 1 1] plane to form a 2D layer (Figure b). 2 and 4 have similar structural features, and only one of the two N donors in the terminal group of L 3 coordinates to AgI, although both N donors have the same probabilities to take part in coordination. Only the more stable trans configuration of L 3 is adopted in 4 and different [Ag2 L 3 ]4 units with respect to 2 are observed maybe due to the different configuration of L 3 .

elements.content: From above discussion, it is clear that the nature of the anions and the coordination ability of the solvent have a profound effect on the network formation. In addition, only N donors of L 3 coordinate to AgI in the presence of CH3CN and ClO4 - in 5, which is similar to that in 3. Meanwhile, only one of the two N atoms of pyrimidine ring could take part in coordination in 4 and 5, which was also observed in other AgI complexes with pyrimidine-2-thiolate derivatives.

elements.content: {[Ag L 4 CH 3 CN](ClO 4 )} ∝ 6. In the 1D complex 6, the geometry of AgI is a slightly distorted “T-type” trigonal planar comprised of two pyrimidine N donors from distinct L 4 ligands and an N donor of CH3CN. All Ag−N bond lengths fall in the range of 2.217(4)−2.577(6) Å, among which the Ag−NCH3CN distance is slightly longer (see Table ). The AgI center deviates from the coordination plane by 0.16(1) Å, and the N(1)−Ag(1)−N(3) angle approaches to linear. Two pyrimidine rings within each ligand are almost coplanar with the dihedral angle of 2.1°, and the dihedral angles between them and the coordination plane are 4.1 and 6.0°, respectively.

The difference between L 4 and L 3 is that one CH3 group is introduced to the terminal group of L 4 . Under the same reaction conditions, a 1D complex 6 was obtained using L 4 instead of L 3 . However, the conformation of the ligand is different from 5. In 6, one L 4 bridges two AgI centers with two N donors of different pyrimidine rings to form a zigzag chain along the c-direction (Figure a) with AgI atoms arranging in two parallel lines, instead of a linear motif as that in 5. All ligands adopt a trans configuration with the bridged Ag···Ag distance of 12.58(2) Å, and the two parallel terminal pyrimidine groups stretch to the opposite directions with respect to the central double bond, with the pseudo-torsion angle C(1)−S(1)···S(1A)−C(1A) of 180°. Perchlorate anions lie inside the hollow of the zigzag chain and CH3CN located at its two side. The AgI center in one chain also shows weak interactions as that in 5 with one S of the adjacent parallel chain with a Ag···S distance of 3.02(2) Å, and these weak interactions link the 1D chains into a double-chain architecture (Figure b), which is different to 5.

elements.content: The structural difference in 5 and 6 may be attributed to the steric resistance or an electronic effect of the 4-methyl of the terminal group in L 4 , which leads to no coordination of the 3-site N atom and only the 1-site N atom coordinates to the AgI center, resulting in more stable trans configuration of L 4 and different 1D zigzag motif compared to 5. This result provides us a feasible strategy for controlling the structures of the complexes by introducing the steric groups to the ligand.

{[Ag L 5 ] 2 (ClO 4 ) 2 (CHCl 3 ) 0.5 } ∝ 7. Complex 7 is a 3D coordination framework, in which the geometry of AgI is a slightly distorted tetrahedron comprised of four N donors from thiadiazole rings of four distinct L 5 ligands. All Ag−N bond distances fall in the range of 2.332(3)−2.381(3) Å (Table ). Two N atoms of each thiadiazole ring bridge two AgI ions [linked as Ag(1A)−N(1)−N(2)−Ag(1)], and two such bridges form a six-membered centrosymmetric dinuclear ring with a Ag···Ag nonbonding distance of 4.25(3) Å. Further, such ring units propagate by sharing the AgI center to form a [-Ag(1C)−Ag(1A)−Ag(1)−Ag(1B)−Ag(1D)-] n zigzag chain along the a direction (Figure a). These 1D chains are further connected through Ag−N coordination, extending along the b and c directions to form a 3D network (Figure b). All ligands adopt a trans configuration and the two terminal thiadiazole groups are parallel, lying on the two sides of the repeating chains alternatively. In addition, the ClO4 - anions and CHCl3 are encapsulated inside the cavities of the 3D network.

All Ag-N bond distances fall in the range of 2.332(3)-2.381(3) Å (Table ). In addition, the ClO4 - anions and CHCl3 are encapsulated inside the cavities of the 3D network.

elements.content: [Ag( L 5 ) 0.5 (BF 4 )(CH 3 CN)] ∝ 8. Complex 8 is a 1D polymer consisting of centrosymmetric dimeric [Ag2 L 5 (BF4)2(CH3CN)2] units. The AgI center adopts a distorted tetrahedron geometry, comprised of two N donors from two thiadiazole rings of distinct L 5 ligands, one N atom of CH3CN and one F atom of a BF4 - anion. All Ag−donor distances fall in the range expected for such coordination bonds (Table ). Two N−N bridges of two thiadiazole rings from distinct L 5 ligands link adjacent AgI centers [Ag(1) and Ag(1A)] with the Ag···Ag separation of 3.704 Å, forming a six-membered metallacyclic unit with a chair configuration. The adjacent dinuclear units are linked by the alkyl groups of the ligand to form a 1D chain (Figure a). All the 1D chains are parallel to each other in the crystal packing, and all BF4 - anions lie on the two sides of the 1D chain. Interestingly, the relatively weaker interactions between the F atoms (F···F distance of 2.83(2) Å) assemble such 1D chains into a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure b).

elements.content: From the structures of 7 and 8, we note that 2-thiothiadiazolyl group shows a different coordination ability with other terminal groups mentioned above, and only N donors take part in coordination, which influences the coordination mode of AgI and the structural topology of the coordination network. The differences between 7 and 8 also show that anion and solvent have important effects on the structures due to their different coordination ability, shape, and size. Comparing such structures, we also can find the formation of the lower dimensional structures of 3, 5, 6, and 8 maybe attributed to the coordination of the acetonitrile, which blocks one of the coordination sites of the AgI center.

elements.content: In summary, eight novel AgI coordination polymers based on five closely related di-arylthioether ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized, giving from 1D to 3D metal−organic coordination architectures. Combining other reported AgI complexes (Table ) with related ligands, we can see that the introduction of N donors into the terminal groups of ligands, and the variations of their numbers and the relative orientations produce different frameworks in which the AgI centers have different coordination environments. These offer a suitable example for exploring the balance of electronic and steric effects in the coordination chemistry of S,N-containing ligands. Generally, the S donor prefers to coordinate to AgI compared to N; however, due to the electronic effects and steric hindrances, almost all N donors in the ligands reported here take part in coordination but not the S donors. In addition, the counteranions and solvents also influence the coordination modes of AgI and the resulting networks. Such results reveal that the nature of the ligand is the determining factor in controlling the structural topologies of their metal−organic supramolecular architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, eight novel AgI coordination polymers based on five closely related di-arylthioether ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized, giving from 1D to 3D metal-organic coordination architectures. Combining other reported AgI complexes (Table ) with related ligands, we can see that the introduction of N donors into the terminal groups of ligands, and the variations of their numbers and the relative orientations produce different frameworks in which the AgI centers have different coordination environments. These offer a suitable example for exploring the balance of electronic and steric effects in the coordination chemistry of S,N-containing ligands. Generally, the S donor prefers to coordinate to AgI compared to N; however, due to the electronic effects and steric hindrances, almost all N donors in the ligands reported here take part in coordination but not the S donors. In addition, the counteranions and solvents also influence the coordination modes of AgI and the resulting networks. Such results reveal that the nature of the ligand is the determining factor in controlling the structural topologies of their metal-organic supramolecular architectures.
